[[James Caan (entrepreneur)|James Caan]], [[Natasha Khan]] |poptime = '''Estimated at around 200,000'''
2.2% of London's population
(20% of the total [[British Pakistani|Pakistani population in the UK]]){{cite web |url =http://www.bl.uk/popups/apkdemog.html |title = Percentage distribution of Pakistani population UK-wide |date = April 2001 |publisher = The British Library |accessdate = 2009-05-30}}{{cite web |url=http://nrifm.com/BLFolder/blpolupation.htm |title=British Asian Demographics |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Non-Resident Indians |accessdate=4 August 2011}} |popplace = '''[[London]]'''
[[London Borough of Newham|Newham]], [[Waltham Forest]], [[London Borough of Redbridge|Redbridge]], [[Hounslow]], [[London Borough of Brent|Brent]], [[Ealing]], [[Croydon]], [[London Borough of Harrow|Harrow]], [[Barking & Dagenham]], [[Wandsworth]], [[Hillingdon]], [[Barnet]] |langs = [[English Language|English]] ([[British English]], [[Pakistani English]]){{Â·}} [[Punjabi language|Punjabi]] {{Â·}}[[Urdu Language|Urdu]] and [[Languages of Pakistan|others]] |rels = Majority [[Islam]] (92%)
Minority [[Christianity]] (1%) |related = [[British Asian|Asian British]]{{Â·}} [[Pakistani diaspora|Overseas Pakistanis]]{{Â·}} [[Demographics of Pakistan|Pakistani people]] }} The '''Pakistani community of London''' (also called '''London Pakistanis''') consist of [[Pakistan]]i emigrants and their descendants who have settled in [[London]], the capital city of [[England]] and the [[United Kingdom]]. Pakistanis in London are the largest concentrated community of [[British Pakistanis]]; people from regions which are now part of Pakistan began to settle in London even before the country's [[Pakistan Movement|independence]].{{cite web | url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/london/content/articles/2005/05/26/pakistan_london_feature.shtml | title = Pakistani London | publisher = BBC | date = 2005-05-26 | accessdate = 2009-05-30}} Whilst British Pakistanis who live in other parts of the UK such as [[Birmingham]], [[Bradford]], [[Oldham]] and the surrounding towns originate predominantly from the [[Mirpur, Azad Kashmir|Mirpur]] area of the [[Azad Kashmir|Kashmir]] region, Pakistanis in London represent a more diverse mixture of [[South Asian]] subgroups including [[Baloch people|Balochis]], [[Punjabi people|Punjabis]], [[Kashmiri people|Kashmiris]], [[Pashtun people|Pashtuns]], [[Muhajirs (Pakistan)|Muhajirs]] and smaller numbers of [[Sindhi people|Sindhis]] among others.{{cite web | url = http://www.communities.gov.uk/documents/communities/pdf/1170952.pdf | title = The Pakistani Muslim Community in England | publisher= The Change Institute, [[Department for Communities and Local Government]] | date = March 2009 | accessdate = 2009-05-30}} A substantial number of British Pakistanis who arrived to London in the 1960s were qualified Teachers, Doctors and Engineers. ==Demographics== [[File:Pakistanis in London.jpg|thumb|250px|left|The Pakistani community of London, top seven Boroughs (according to ''[[The Guardian]]'') {{cite news |author=The Guardian|title=London by ethnicity|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/graphic/0,5812,1395103,00.html|accessdate=2009-06-25}}]] Pakistanis in London are mostly [[Muslim]]s who speak [[Urdu language|Urdu]] and [[Punjabi language|Punjabi]] amongst other languages.{{cite web |url=http://www.20thcenturylondon.org.uk/server.php?show=conInformationRecord.166 |title=20thcentury Pakistani London |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Renaissance London |accessdate=4 August 2011}} The main concentrations of Pakistani settlement in London are, North East, West and South West London. Newham is home to 15% of all London Pakistanis.{{cite web |url=http://www.lse.ac.uk/collections/londonDevelopmentWorkshops/migrationSeminar/Presentations/migrationIntoBritian_LondonsPlaceInTheWiderPicture.pdf |title=Migration into Britain Londonâs place in the wider picture |author= |page=11 |work= |publisher=[[London School of Economics]] |accessdate=4 August 2011}} {|class="wikitable" ! align="left" | Region ! align="left" | Population ! align="left" | Pakistani population ! align="left" | Pakistanis as a % ! align="centre" | Main Boroughs (%) |- | [[Greater London]]{{cite web | url = http://neighbourhood.statistics.gov.uk/dissemination/LeadTableView.do?a=3&b=276743&c=London&d=13&e=13&g=325264&i=1001x1003x1004&m=0&r=1&s=1200166746953&enc=1&dsFamilyId=1809 | title = Resident Population Estimates by Ethnic Group, All Persons; City of London (Local Authority) | publisher = Neighbourhood Statistics, Office of National Statistics | date = June 2006 | accessdate = 2009-05-30}} | 7,456,100 | 200,000 | 2.2% | [[London Borough of Newham|Newham]] (8.7%)
[[Waltham Forest]] (7.7%)

| [[London]] | 7,172,091 | 7,560,000{{cite news| url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/3085513/London-population-soars-by-more-than-half-a-million-in-decade.html | work=The Daily Telegraph | title=London population soars by more than half a million in decade | date=2008-09-26 | accessdate=2010-05-20}} | 142,749 | 170,500 | 2.0 | 2.3 |- | [[File:Flag of England.svg|25px]][[File:Flag of Wales 2.svg|25px]] [[England and Wales]] | 52,041,916 | 54,450,000{{cite web |url=http://www.statistics.gov.uk/cci/nugget.asp?id=1352 |title=UK population projections |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Office for National Statistics |accessdate=4 August 2011}} | 714,828 | 916,700{{cite web |url=http://www.statistics.gov.uk/downloads/theme_population/Tables_EE1-EE6_2007.xls population |accessdate=4 August 2011}}] | 747,285 | 977,285 | 1.3 | 1.7 |} Note: (Est) - Estimated Source: '''2001'''{{cite web |url=http://legacy.london.gov.uk/gla/publications/factsandfigures/dmag-update-2008-03.pdf |title=Round Ethnic Group Projections |author= |date=2007 |work= |publisher=''[[Greater London Authority]]'' |accessdate=4 August 2011}} ==Religion== In similarity to [[Pakistan]]is living other parts of the UK, 92% of Pakistanis in [[London]] are [[Muslim]]s. The other 6% are made up of people who did not declare their religion, [[Christian]]s make up 2% and those with no religion made up 1%. Pakistanis make up only 22% of [[London]]'s Muslim population, in contrast to 43% for British Pakistanis living throughout the UK. ==Economics== The main industries which the Pakistani community of London are employed in include [[wholesale]] and [[retail]] (including self-owned grocery stores or newsagents). In 2001, 0.6% of businesses in London were owned by British Pakistanis.{{cite web | url = http://www.museumoflondon.org.uk/English/Collections/Onlineresources/RWWC/themes/1084/1193 | title= Pakistani London | publisher = [[Museum of London]] | accessdate = 2009-05-30}} 20% of London's Pakistani population are self-employed. The percentage of London Pakistanis employed in managerial, senior official or professional occupations is 33%, which is slightly higher than the London average of 32%. It is also higher than the percentage of London Bangladeshis (22%) and similar to the percentage of Indians (34%) and Other Asians (31%).{{cite web |url=http://www.london.gov.uk/gla/publications/factsandfigures/DMAG_briefing2005-4.pdf |title=Pakistani community of London |author= |date= |work= |publisher=London Assembly |accessdate=4 August 2011}} The unemployment rate for Pakistani males and females in London is lower than the national average British Pakistanis living in other regions of Britain. Pakistanis are the only ethnic group (along with White Britions) who have a lower worklessness rate in London than in other areas of Britain.{{cite web | url = http://www.london.gov.uk/mayor/economic_unit/worklessness/Pam_Meadows.pdf | last =Meadows | first = Pam | title = Worklessness in London: why is it higher than in the rest of the country? | publisher = http://www.london.gov.uk | accessdate = 2009-05-30}} ==Social class== As of 2001, almost equal amounts of Pakistanis in Inner (45%) and Outer London (46%) were [[middle class]]. ===Middle class by Borough=== [[File:London Pakistani Middle Class.jpg|300px|thumb|London Pakistani middle class]] {| class="wikitable" |- ! Borough || Pakistani middle class || Overall middle class |- | Waltham Forest || 44% || N/A |- | Haringey || 36% || N/A |- | Newham || 32% || 37% |- |} Source:{{cite web |url=http://books.google.co.uk/books?id=fBJLH49xa-YC&dq=London's+turning:+Thames+Gateway-prospects+and+legacy&printsec=frontcover&source=bl&ots=D6YdnpNvXa&sig=E7Wiie0Aiti9bYfWoqASmwQ_Wx8&hl=en&ei=LdeTSoqOJ96OjAfwm9GADg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1#v=onepage&q=pakistani%20middle%20class&f |author=Philip Cohen and Michael J. Rustin |title=London's turning: Thames Gateway London's turning, The Making of Thames Gateway |date= |work= |publisher=Ashgate |accessdate=4 August 2011}} Between 1991 and 2001, out of the total growth in the London Pakistani population, 52.7% of the growth was in the middle classes. ===Growth in the middle class as a proportion of all growth=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Region || Growth |- | England & Wales || 36.4% |- | South East || 39.6% |- | Greater London || 52.7% |- | Outer London || 52.6% |- | Inner London || 52.8% |- |} Source: Growth in managers and professionals as a proportion was 22.8% between 1991 and 2001. ===Growth in managers and professionals as a proportion of all growth=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Region || Growth |- | England & Wales || 15.8% |- | South East || 18% |- | Greater London || 22.8% |- | Outer London || 22.6% |- | Inner London || 23.5% |- |} Source: There are stark social differences in Pakistanis living in different boroughs of London. Whilst in [[London Borough of Brent|Brent]] and [[Harrow (London Borough)|Harrow]] London Pakistanis are fairly prosperous and mostly Middle Class. The opposite is true in [[Newham]], where they are mostly working class and more likely to suffer from deprivation.{{cite web |url=http://www.iomlondon.org/doc/mapping/Pakistan%20Mapping%20Exercise%20Final%20Report.pdf Pakistani mapping exercise |title=Pakistan Mapping Exercise |author= |date= |page=11 |publisher=IOM London |accessdate=4 August 2011}} Several [[upper class]] Pakistanis also live in London, sometimes only for part of the year. The former presidents of Pakistan [[Nawaz Sharif]] and [[Pervez Musharraf]] currently reside in London.{{cite web |url=http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/standard/article-23742291-pervez-musharrafs-london-pad-surrounded-by-kebab-joints.do |title=Pervez Musharraf's London pad surrounded by kebab joints |author=Peter Dominiczak |date=10.09.09 |work= |publisher=''[[London Evening Standard]]'' |accessdate=31 May 2010}}{{cite web |url=http://www.dailytimes.com.pk/default.asp?page=2010\05\19\story_19-5-2010_pg7_27 |title=Baroness Warsi calls on Nawaz Sharif |author= |date=May 19, 2010 |work= |publisher=Daily Times |accessdate=31 May 2010}} ==Education== ===Key Stage 2=== At [[Key Stage 2]] Pakistani children in London have higher attainment rates in both English and Maths, when compared with the British Pakistani average.{{cite web |url=http://google.com/search?q=cache:07zFBWtGTA4J:www.dcsf.gov.uk/citychallenge/downloads/00481-2008DOM-EN%255B1%255D.pdf+Vision+for+London+2008+2011+London+Education+on+the+way+to+world+class+Pakistani&cd=1&hl=en&ct=clnk&gl |title=UK Vision for London 2008 - 2011 |author=DSCF |date= |work= |publisher=[[Department for Children, Schools and Families]] |accessdate=4 August 2011}} ===GCSEs=== In contrast to Pakistanis from other regions of Britain. Pakistanis in London achieve above average [[GCSE]] Pass Rates. For example, in 2004, 50.2% of London Pakistani boys achieved five or more A*-C grades, compared with the national average of 46.8%. Furthermore, 63.3% of Pakistani girls in London reached that threshold compared to the national average of 57%.{{cite book | last = Richardson | first = Robin | coauthors = Angela Wood | url = http://www.insted.co.uk/raising2005.pdf | title = The Achievement of British Pakistani Learners | year = 2004 | accessdate = 2009-05-30 | publisher = Trentham Books, in association with the Uniting Britain Trust, Ltd.}} ===GCSE Pass Rates (5 A*-Cs) by London Borough=== [[File:London Pakistanis GCSE Pass Rates 5 A-Cs by Borough.jpg|300px|thumb|London Pakistani GCSE Pass Rates by Borough]] Latest figures available, regarding London Pakistanis, by local authority, dated: year 2004. {| class="wikitable" |- ! Borough || Pass Rate |- | Redbridge || 64.9% |- | Ealing || 54.0% |- | Newham || 52.7% |- | colspan=2| ''England Average (All Ethnic Groups) (2004): 51.9%'' |- | Waltham Forest || 49.9% |- | colspan=2| ''British Pakistani Average (2004): 45.2%'' |- |} The achievement of Pakistanis in London at GCSE level is 10 percentage points higher than that of Pakistanis throughout England. ===Degree Level Qualifications=== [[File:Degree Level Qualifications.jpg|294px|thumb|rigft|Degree Level Qualifications]] Pakistani applicants to universities are over-represented by 7.5% from Greater London. In education, Pakistanis in London performed the highest out of all [[British Pakistanis]] in the 2001 census. This is not just reflected in above average GCSE pass rates but also in degree level qualifications, with 32% of London Pakistanis having degree level or higher qualifications. This is marginally higher than the London average of 31% and is more than twice as high as the figure for London Bangladeshis (15%), equal to the figure for "Other Asians" and comparable to the figure of 34% for London Indians. Pakistanis in Inner London do slightly better than those in Outer London, with 33% reaching the benchmark compared to 32% in Outer London. The figure is higher than the national average of 20% and almost twice as high as the figure for Pakistanis throughout the UK (18%). Pakistani men are better qualified than the average Londoner, with 37% possessing a degree level or higher qualification, although Pakistani women have fewer educational qualifications, with 27% having the same qualifications. The figure for Pakistani women in London is still higher than the national or British Pakistani national average.{{cite web | url = http://static.london.gov.uk/gla/publications/factsandfigures/DMAG_briefing2005-4.pdf | title = 2001 Census Profiles: Pakistanis in London | last = Piggott | first = Gareth | date = 4 January 2005 | publisher = Data Management and Analysis Group | accessdate = 2010-10-15}} ==Notable Londoners of Pakistani origin== * [[Sir Anwar Pervez]] - A Pakistan-born businessman who was estimated by [[The Times]] to be Britainâs richest [[Muslim]] in 2010.{{cite news |url=http://business.timesonline.co.uk/tol/business/industry_sectors/leisure/article7078235.ece |title=Asian entrepreneurs present best way to succeed |author=Catherine Boyle |date= 27 March 2010|work= |publisher=''Times Newspapers'' |accessdate=15 July 2011 |location=London}} Founder of the [[Bestway|Bestway Group]].{{cite news |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2002/jun/17/religion.immigrationpolicy |title=The winners |author=Paul Kelso |date= 17 June 2002|work= |publisher=''Guardian News and Media'' |accessdate=15 July 2011 |location=London}} His company is based in [[Brent]] though he now lives with his family in [[Beaconsfield]], South Bucks.{{cite web |url=http://www.asian-whoswho.com/viewasian.asp?aid=10 |title=ASIAN OF THE YEAR 1997-98 Sir Mohammed Anwar Pervez OBE |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Asian who's who |accessdate=4 August 2011}} * [[Hanif Kureishi]] - Playwright, screenwriter and filmmaker, novelist and short story writer.{{cite news |url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/international/article2057790.ece |title=Pakistan is in terminal decline |author=Hasan Suroor |date= 28 May 2011|work= |publisher=''The Hindu'' |accessdate=15 July 2011 |location=Chennai, India}} * [[Owais Shah]] - A [[Karachi]] origin cricketer who plays for [[Middlesex County Cricket Club|Middlesex]] and has appeared for England in a number of One Day Internationals and test matches.{{cite news |url=http://www.independent.co.uk/sport/cricket/shah-happy-in-look-and-learn-mode-660054.html |title=Shah happy in look and learn mode |author=Stephen Brenkley |date= 10 February 2002|work= |publisher=''[[The Independent]]'' |accessdate=15 July 2011 |location=London}} * [[Riz Lateef]] - A news reader for [[BBC London News]] and the BBC Deputy News Manager.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/local/london/hi/tv_and_radio/newsid_8079000/8079000.stm Riz Lateef] BBC London Presenter Profile, 8 June 2009 ==See also== *[[Pakistan â United Kingdom relations]] *[[List of British Asian people]] *[[British Asian]] *[[British Pakistani]] *[[List of British people of Pakistani descent]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Overseas Pakistani}} {{AsiansinUK}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Pakistani Community Of London}} [[Category:Ethnic groups in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:British people of Pakistani descent| ]] [[Category:Pakistani diaspora in the United Kingdom| ]]
